New Records: Jackson Chourio became the youngest player to hit a leadoff homer in the postseason.
Chourio is the second-youngest player to homer twice in a postseason game, behind 19-year-old Andruw Jones for Atlanta in the 1996 World Series opener at Yankee Stadium.
Milwaukee had been 0-26 in the postseason when trailing going into the eighth inning, according to MLB.com.
Key Match Events: Jackson Chourio tied the game in the eighth with his second homer of the night.
Garrett Mitchell delivered a two-run shot in the eighth inning to give the Milwaukee Brewers a 5-3 victory.
Devin Williams retired the side in order in the ninth to earn the save.
Joe Ross picked up the win after pitching 1 1/3 innings of scoreless relief.
Post-Match Reflections: Mitchell said, 'We talk about it every night: Win tonight. Do whatever it takes.'
Chourio said through a translator, 'It's just been an incredible year. There's not much more to say than that. It's been an incredible year for everyone, for all the guys in that clubhouse.'

Pete Alonso said, 'Obviously, losing’s not fun, but we’ve been responding to adversity all year. I’m really excited for this challenge tomorrow. I know they’re equally as excited. This is what the playoffs are all about.'
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Brewers will attempt to become the first team to win a best-of-three Wild Card Series after losing the opener since MLB went to this expanded playoff format in 2022.
The teams will play a decisive Game 3 on Thursday night.
The game was held at American Family Field with an attendance of 40,350.
